Union will get rid of duplicate so only 1 row remaining

Selected Answer: D
It is not union all to return duplicated rows

D checked 

select 1 as id, 'john' as first_name from dual
union
select 1, 'john' as name from dual order by 1;
Because both rows are the same, the UNION result gives distinct answers

comments.content: my mistake D is the correct answer

yes union all only gives duplicate so it will be 2 rows
but union will give 1 row eliminating the duplicates

discussion.content: Option-B is the correct choose

Selected Answer: D
INTERSECT will only keep rows that exists for both tables so only 1 row remaining

Selected Answer: D
Checked

D tested 
select 1 as id, 'john' as first_name, NULL as commission from dual
intersect
select 1, 'john' as name, null from dual order by 3;

Selected Answer: D
It returns 1 row, because the values are the same. I do tested as well
tested on 19c, returns 0 rows.

discussion.content: the answer is A and B tested
how did u extract only text from this text image
AB tested
why is D wrong?

comments.content: It gives this error ORA-01722: invalid number. Also, there is no point in converting this to char, It can not parse it correctly. This needs to be converted to date first.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BCD
A is not successful DML

Selected Answer: BCD
For A to be true the statement would have to be syntactically valid.

Should be BCD:
A - FALSE
- it is syntax error therefore does not implicitly commit: Oracle Database issues an implicit COMMIT under the following circumstances:

Before any syntactically valid data definition language (DDL) statement, even if the statement results in an error

After any data definition language (DDL) statement that completes without an errorhttps://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/19/sqlrf/COMMIT.html#GUID-6CD5C9A7-54B9-4FA2-BA3C-D6B4492B9EE2

Selected Answer: BCD
A is wrong, ddl is still in compilation mode, so no ddl considered.

comments.content: A works. It commits before and after every ddl statement so A will implicitly commit despite failing due to a syntax error

discussion.content:
A - false since it is syntax error (checked ) if it is run time error then it commits the transaction. 
B is true The SHUTDOWN TRANSACTIONAL waits for all uncommitted transactions to complete before shutting down the database instance. This saves the work for all users without requesting them to log off.

BCD would be the right answer

Selected Answer: ACD
Chat GPT says A is correct and B is wrong.
as SHUTDOWN TRANSACTIONAL functionality is that it waits all transactions to end then it shuts down the database, but he says since it was 'successful' then that means that the database already was shut down before the user committed.
I think there is some logical problem with the answer.. its confusing, how is it successful but there was still a transaction in progress?

ALTER TABLE and CREATE INDEX , which do cause a commit.
Oracle performs an implicit commit after any SQL DDL (Data Definition Language) statement (even if this DDL statement fails).

This includes table / index creation. So no open transaction should exist.

I CHECKED making an experiment and A IS CORRECT answer.
Looks like just CREATE TABLE AS creates a COMMIT (error was placed later - I used unexisting table as a source)
Don't know why A is correct answer

comments.content: Because before any DDL instructions, there is an implicit COMMIT

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BCD
BCD is correct.

Selected Answer: BCD
B should be correct, because the session will be killed after the last transaction will be committed or the user will use rollback... A is incorrect because the statement failed with a syntax error

why is not B?
C used SQLPLUS is right but use sql developer ....Maybe not

choices.C: when the session logs out successfully
choices.D: when a CREATE INDEX statement is executed successfully in the same session
choices.E: when a DBA issues a successful SHUTDOWN IMMEDIATE statement and the user then issues a COMMIT
choices.A: when a CREATE TABLE AS SELECT statement is issued in the same session but fails with a syntax error
choices.B: when a DBA issues a successful SHUTDOWN TRANSACTIONAL statement and the user then issues a COMMIT
choices.F: when a COMMIT statement is issued by the same user from another session in the same database instance

questions.question_text:
An Oracle Database session has an uncommitted transaction in progress which updated 5000 rows in a table.
In which three situations does the transaction complete thereby committing the updates? (Choose three.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AE
Its A & E not D.
why? read below
D. The foreign key constraint will be disabled. 
This is incorrect because the question states that the SQL statements execute successfully, so the foreign key constraint would typically be enabled, not disabled.
Never knew what DEFERRED was. One keeps, learning every day.

Selected Answer: AD
DEFERRED: allows to make insertions and updates without immediate validation, only when you commit

Selected Answer: AD
AD is the correct answer
What does it mean by IMMEDIATE tho?

is AD
PK enable again

AD
Cascade constraint will disable to primay key as well as foreign key.
AD. Due to the PK being disabled, the FK is disabled. PK afterwards is enabled again

choices.E: The foreign key constraint will be enabled and IMMEDIATE.
choices.D: The foreign key constraint will be disabled.
choices.C: The primary key constraint will be enabled and DEFERRED.
choices.A: The primary key constraint will be enabled and IMMEDIATE.
choices.B: The foreign key constraint will be enabled and DEFERRED.
